Prior to commencing work on site, each contractor employee receives a safety orientation by the Safety Department. The safety orientation covers information on the hazards associated with the process areas where the work will be performed, safety procedures and systems to be sued, overview of the site emergency response program including specific procedures to be followed in case of an emergency, and a review of site safety rules and applicable operating procedures. A record of each contractor employee's sign-off on the safety orientation is maintained on file at the site, including the date the training was completed. Once the safety orientation is complete, the contractor is responsible to ensure that each contractor employee performs the assigned  work in a manner consistent with the information provided during the safety orientation. If the contractor assigns new employees to the job after work has commenced, the contractor must also ensure that each new employee receives a safety orientation prior to starting work on site. Failure of the contractor or any contractor employee to abide by these requirements is grounds for immediate dismissal from the site.

4) The Five Year Accident History:

During the past 5 years there have been no accidental releases of Ammonia or Propane for IWI Farmers Valley Plant, that meet the reporting requirements of the RMP rule.

5) The Emergency Response P

lan

The IWI Farmers Valley Plant has an Emergency Response Program for the purpose of protecting employees, contractors, public health and the environment. The program includes a written Emergency response Plan, employee training in emergency response procedures, procedures to review and update the plan, and procedures for the use, inspection, testing, and maintenance of emergency response equipment.

The Emergency Response Plan includes procedures for emergency response after an accidental release of Ammonia or Propane at the plant. The Emergency response Plan also includes procedures for administering first aid and emergency care.

The Emergency Response Plan includes notification procedures for informing the public and outside agencies in case an accidental release occurs. Outside agencies such as fire departments, the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and state environmental agencies are notified according to regulatory reporting requirements and as neceddary to provide or assist with the emergency response.

The Emergency Rsponse Plan is coordinated with the LEPC, and information in the plan is readily available to the local emergency response officials for the purpose of developing and implementing the communit emergency response plans.

Offsite community response activities are implemented in accordance with the community emergency response plans as developed by the LEPC. Representatives from the IWI Farmers Valley Plant meet regularly with the LEPC to review procedues, training requirements, equipment needs, and to conduct emergency response exercises.

The facility Emergency Response Plan has been communicated to the McKean County Emergency Management Agency. Drills utilizing facility personnel, local fire departments, county emergency medical and state and local police departments have been planned, to test the updated Emergency Rsponse Procedures. Additional internal training drills and exercises have been conducted, including with Butler Communi

d in the Offsite Emergency response Plan for the IWIW Farmers Valley Plant developed and maintained by the McKean County LEPC.

6) Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Following a series of detailed revalidation Process Hazards Analysis recently completed for the MEK unit and PDA unit, specific recommendations will be subject to Management Review and then trac

ked through the plant's Action Item Tracking System. These actions will focus on further reducing the risk of releasing Ammonia or Propane. Recommnedations made include:

a) Changes to plant operating procedures
b) Improvements to plant instrumentation and control
c) Installing chemical detection equipment
d) Installing additional safety systems, including shutdown and isolation systems.


Some of these recommendations have already been implemented (eg: Procedures, Ammonia sensing equipment) or are in the process of being evaluated for implementation. Specific details are available through the plant's Action Item Tracking System.

Written procedures have been prepard to define the scope and requirements of the Mechanical Integrity program. Maintenance employees involved in carrying out the Mechanical Integrity program are certified by the Maintenance Manager to complete the required tasks in a safe manner.

One componenet of the Mechanical Integrity program inclueds inspection and testing of equipment handling Propane and Ammonia. Equipment inspection and testing is conducted in accordance with the manufactur's recommendations and generally accepted good engineering practices. Records of inspections and testing are maintained to show the date, equipment identification, inspector, type of test or inspection performed, and test results or observations.

If deficiencies are noted during equipment inspection and testing, corrective actions are taken in a timely manner to assure the safe operation of the process. In some cases, equipment inspections are drvien by permit requirements as well as the Mechanical Integrity program.

3f. Management of Change (MOC)

A Management of Change form is generated when there is a change ( except for replacement in kind) to equipment, process chemicals, technology, procedures, or a change to the facility that will affect a process that handles Ammonia or Propane. Work orders for such changes pass through the Safety Department and Engineering to ensure the proposed change is carefully evaluated before implementation (e.g. to assure that proper materials of construction and good engineering practices are employed). Engineering will make changes to the P&ID's to keep the Process Safety Information up to date. Operations and Maintenance personnel are trained prior to start up of a modified process.

3j. Employee Participation

All employees at the IWI Farmers Valley plant have the oppurtunity to access and participate in the sharing of information relatd to process safety for the processes involving Ammonia nd Propane. Employees in the maintenance and operating areas attend monthly safety meetings to review incidents, learn about new or modified processes, and discuss specific safety topics. Employees routinely have oppurtunities to participate in other safety processes in the accident prevention program. These include Process Hazard Analyses, Management of Change, Employee Training, and Incident Investigation.

3k. Hot Work Permits

The IWI Farmers Valley plant has an established Hot Work permit program. Hot Work operations include burning, welding, drilling, grinding, torch cutting or other spark producing activity. Under the program, a hot work permit must be issued prior to commencing hot work operations in the Ammonia and Propane units. The hot work permit indicates the type and method of hot work to be conducted, the equipment that the hot work will be performed on, the date, time, and location authorized for the hot work, the presence of fire prevention and protection systems meeting the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.252(a), and signatures of the supervisory employees authorizing the hot work. A spereate Hot Work permit must be issued for each Hot Work operation, and a spsereate Hot Work permit must be issued for each day. A copy of the Hot Work permit must be displayed at the job location while hot work is in progress, and the permit is maintained on file after the completion of the Hot Work.

INTERNATIONAL WAXES INCORPORATED (IWI) FARMERS VALLEY, PA PLANT

The Farmers Valley plant is a manufacturing facility located in Smethport, Mckean County, PA. It is a wholey owned subsidiary of the International Group Incorporated (IGI) of Ontario, Canada. IGI is the largest independent wax refiner and blender in North America, with refineries in Canada and the United States.

Health, Safety, and EnvironmentalResponsibility

IWI and it parent body IGI are committed to managing health, safety, and the environment as a core business value. The company integrates health, safety, and environemntal management into all aspects of business as a competitive advantage in achieving profitable growth and accelerated productivity.

The IWI Farmers Valley plant is a wax manufacturing facility that has approximately 117 employees. The plant's products are used to make specialty waxes, including micro-crystalline waxes for the food and beverage industries.

Due to various regulated substances handled at the IWI Farmers Valley, the plant is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations (29 CFR 1910.119(e) and the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule (40 CFR Part 68).

Armp regulated substances include Anyhdrous Ammonia and Propane. The plant's storage and use of these chemicals exceeds the specified thresholds of 10,000 lbs.

In accordance with the requirements of the RMP Rule, a description of the following sis elements are provided for the IWI Farmers Valley plant:

1) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is the goal of the IWI Farmers Valley plant to operate a safe and environementally soind facility by indentifying and controlling health, safety, and environmental risks related to its operations by:

a) Designing, operating, and maintaining its processes to protect people, property and the environement;
b) Conducting and continually reviewing and improving programs for safety, health, and environmental management;
c) Establishing

eps:

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program at the IWI Farmers Valley plant consists of 12 elements. Each of these elements are components of the sites PSM Program summarised below.

3a. Process Safety Information

Written Process Safety Information (PSI) has been compiled for the MEK and PDA Units by the plant's Engineering Department. The information compiled includes:

a) Data on the safe use and handling of Ammonia and Propane (e.g. Material Safety Data Sheets);
b) Data on the process technology (e.g. process flow diagrams, process chemistry, flow rates, storage capacities, operating limits and evaluation of the consequences of deviation);
c) Data on the equipment used in the process (e.g. piping and instrument diagrams, materials compatibility, energy ratings and classification, control devices and emergency systems, ventilation systems, and design basis including conformance to applicable codes and standards).

PSI for the MEK and PDA Untis were generated before and during the Process Hazard Analyses for the process that use Ammonia and Propane. This enables the employees involved in operating these processes to indentify and understand the potential hazards associated with the process. These PSI were updated in 2007 to include the following information.
A) Corrosivity data
b)  Thermal and chemical stability data
c) Ventilation system design data
d) Design codes and standards employed
e) Material and energy balances
f) Safety systems.

3b. Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs)

Revalidation PHA studies for the processes involving Ammonia and Propane have been completed in accordance with PSM Regulations using the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) technique. Each Process Hazard Analysis addresses aspects including process hazards, process incident history, process control devices, equipment location, and human factors. A team of employees having experience and knowledge of the process design, operation and maintenance, and knowledge of how to complete a PHA p

erforms each study. An Action Item Tracking System and the plant's Management of Change (MOC) process described below is used to track and document process changes, which occur as a result of recommendations from the Process Hazard Analyses.

3c. Safe Operating Procedures

Written operating procedures are prepared for all processes at the facility, including those using Ammonia and Propane. The operating procedures provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities in the plant. Procedures are updated to reflect current operating practices, and are certified annually for accuracy.

Specific information and instructions covered by operating procedures include startup, normal operation, emergency operation, shutdown, operating limits, operating controls, chemcial-specific health and safety information, required personal protective equipment, and use of safety systems. Written Safety procedures are also provided for specific operations such as Hot Work, Lock-out / Tag-out, Confined Space Entry and Line Breaking.

3d. Training

Employees involved in operating processes using Ammonia dn Propane have received traing to ensure they have the require knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the requirements specified in the written Operating Procedures. Refresher training is provided every three years at a minimum, or sooner if warrented by changes to operating conditions, equipment or procedures. If refresher training is required more frequently than every three years, it will be triggered through the Management of Change process (described below). Training records are maintained for each employee to show the date training was conducted, the material covered by the training, and the means used to verify that the training was understood.
